xxl.core.cursors.sources
Class Inductor<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.sources.Inductor<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
public class Inductor<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

Given a tuple of start values (a0 to an) the inductor incrementally computes the value a(n+1+i) (i ≥ 0) by calling the function next with the parameters ai to a(n+i). Optionally, the user can specify the predicate hasNext (called with parameters ai to a(n+i)) which determines whether a next value exists. With the help of an inductor a sequence of elements can be computed represented as an iteration.

Example usage (1): the Fibonacci sequence 

   Inductor<Integer> fibonacci = new Inductor<Integer>(
       new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
           public Integer invoke(Integer fib_1, Integer fib_2) {
               return fib_1 + fib_2;
           }
       },
       1,
       1
   );
   
   fibonacci.open();
   
   System.out.println(Cursors.nth(fibonacci, 7));
   
   fibonacci.close();
This example computes the 7th number of the fibonacci sequence by initializing the inductor with two integer objects with value 1 (beginning of the induction sequence; n = 1, 2). All following elements are computed with the following function: 
   fib(n) = fib(n-1) + fib(n-2);
Implemenation details: If the next element is available, i.e., the flag nextAvailable is true, the function next is invoked on the list objects. This list is shifted left for one position by removing the first value. Then the returned object is added to this list as the last element with regard to the further computation of the inductor sequence. The first element of the list objects is returned, because this is the next element that has be returned in the inductor sequence. So this inductor would return the next number of the fibonacci sequence as long as the next method is called. In this case the static method nth() is used to return only the 7th number of the sequence, but also an other function hasNext can be specified in a constructor with the intention to terminate such an inductor sequence.

Example usage (2): the factorial method 

   Inductor<Integer> factorial = new Inductor<Integer>(
       new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
           int factor = 1;
           
           public Integer invoke(Integer n) {
               return n * factor++;
           }
       },
       1
   );
   
   factorial.open();
   
   System.out.println(Cursors.nth(factorial, 3));
   
   factorial.close();
This example computes the 3rd number of the factorial method (3! = 6). The induction is initialized by one integer object with value 1 (n = 0). Further elements are iteratively computed by invoking the above defined function: 
   fac(n) = n * fac(n-1);
But the factor, i.e., the next integer to multiply the next element fac(n-1) by, which is written back to the array, has to be stored (in the anonymous class). For further examples see Inductors.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, Inductors, Predicate, Function

Field Detail

hasNext

protected Predicate<? super E> hasNext
The predicate that is used to determine an end of the inductor sequence.

next

protected Function<? super E,? extends E> next
The function that is used to compute the next element of the induction sequence.

objects

protected List<E> objects
A list storing the parameters ai to a(n+i)] required for the computation of the value a(n+1+i).

available

protected int available
The number of values of the induction sequence that are available from the list objects.

nextAvailable

protected boolean nextAvailable
A flag to signal if the next element in the sequence is available. The implementation used to set this flag is as follows: 
   nextAvailable = objects.size()==available-- && hasNext.invoke(objects);
So the length of the objects list has to be the start-length, namely available, and the predicate hasNext must be true.

Constructor Detail

Inductor

public Inductor(Predicate<? super E> hasNext,
                Function<? super E,? extends E> next,
                E... objects)
Creates a new inductor with a user defined predicate delivering the end of the induction sequence.

Parameters:
hasNext - the predicate which determines whether a next value exists.
next - the function using parameters ai to a(n+i) (i ≥ 0) to compute the result-value a(n+1+i).
objects - the start-values a0 to an of the induction sequence.

Inductor

public Inductor(Function<? super E,Boolean> hasNext,
                Function<? super E,? extends E> next,
                E... objects)
Creates a new inductor with a user defined boolean function delivering the end of the induction sequence. The boolean function hasNext is internally wrapped to a predicate.

Parameters:
hasNext - the boolean function which determines whether a next value exists.
next - the function using parameters ai to a(n+i) (i ≥ 0) to compute the result-value a(n+1+i).
objects - the start-values a0 to an of the induction sequence.

Inductor

public Inductor(Function<? super E,? extends E> next,
                E... objects)
Creates a new inductor delivering an infinite induction sequence, i.e., the predicate which determines whether a next value exists is given by Predicates.TRUE.

Parameters:
next - the function using parameters ai to a(n+i) (i ≥ 0) to compute the result-value a(n+1+i).
objects - the start-values a0 to an of the induction sequence.
Method Detail

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the indutor has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the inductor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
